Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Collaborative Research: Development of Multifunctional Reactive Electrochemical Membranes for Biomass Recovery with Fouling Reduction, Water Reuse, and Cell Pretreatment

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1603609/1604776/1604886 Zhang, W.; Chaplin, B; Shuai, D.
Title: Multifunctional Electroreactive Membranes for Efficient Biomass Separations

This collaborative research project, involving the New Jersey Institute of Technology, University of Illinois-Chicago, and George Washington University, will address a key research issue to enable the production of fuels and chemical products from biomass resources such as algae. Alga microorganisms are cultivated in fermenters, often in dilute concentration in an aqueous phase. Dewatering of the biomass or algae and recycle and reuse of the cleaned-up water are key fundamental research issues that impact commercial competitiveness. The PIs will research and design efficient, scalable, and multifunctional reactive electrochemical membranes (REMs) to harvest value-added products derived from the biomass (e.g., biofuels and specialty chemicals) in a sustainable manner. Biomass separation using membrane filtration is currently characterized by high operational cost due to severe membrane fouling and the need for frequent backwashing to remove the foulants. The proposed research will use the hybrid membranes to mitigate membrane fouling and to remove the toxic inhibitors that will promote water reuse. The research outcomes will advance the fundamental science and engineering of biomass separations, and potentially lead to critical, transformative technologies for biomass and food processing, drinking water treatment, and biomolecule purification in the pharmaceutical industries.

This principal investigators will use algae as a model biomass organism; and will focus on characterizing membrane fouling, water reuse for algae regrowth, and electrochemical pre-treatment of algal cells. Research tasks will include (1) synthesis and characterization of a suite of tailored monolithic or nanofibrous REMs for algal recovery; (2) evaluation of algae separation efficiency, permeate water treatment, and anti-fouling properties of REMs; (3) elucidation of algae cell disruption efficiency and the underlying mechanisms of electrochemical oxidation using microfluidic experiments; and (4) experimental and theoretical assessment of membrane fouling and regeneration strategies. The fundamental knowledge generated by this project will lead to transformative solutions that address the grand challenges at the energy-water nexus. First, the research will provide fundamental guidelines to the design of REMs with excellent filtration performance, flexible design, and durability of operation. Secondly, the research will promote water and nutrient reuse in waste streams or cultivation media, which reduces the water and energy footprints of renewable energy production. Finally, the project will train and mentor at least three Ph.D. students and a large number of undergraduate and senior high school students that will be recruited from underrepresented groups in STEM at the three collaborating institutions for research experiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project will have three primary outcomes. Firstly, biomass engineering and separation such as algal cell treatment and recovery opens possibilities of algae-based renewable energy acquisition, which  potentially reduces our dependence on fossil fuels; Secondly, biomass separation is crucial for decontamination in water purification and drinking supply. This research aimed to provide unique contributions to these efforts via validating electrochemically reactive membrane filtration systems that incorporate reaction and separation in synergistic ways. The research outcomes therefore promote water treatment, resource recovery, and biomass-enabled products. Thirdly, the project successfully supported a Ph.D. student, four undergraduate and two senior high school students who was recruited through NJIT's undergraduate research innovation and internship programs. Students represent the future leaders of engineering and science, and their participation in this project motivated their academic studies and utilized their knowledge to engineering research, which better prepares them for potential careers in academia, consulting, and government agencies.

This work at NJIT aimed to create one integrated system to tackle several pressing challenges at energy-water nexus of biomass engineering and separation through four phases or stages. The first stage of our research (2015-2016) has demonstrated the use of the Ti4O7-based reactive membrane in algal pretreatment and the positive impacts on lipid extraction. After exposure to the reactive membrane under anodic oxidation, algal cells exhibited disruption in cellular morphology and photosynthetic activity due to the anodic oxidation. Cell lysis was evidenced by the changes of fluorescent patterns of dissolved organic matter (DOM) in the treated algal suspension. The lipid extraction efficiency was shown to increase on those disrupted algal cells. However, excessive oxidation caused decline of the amounts of extractable lipid due to the undesirable oxidation of lipid besides the oxidation of algal cells.  This work highlights the potential to couple algal harvesting via filtration with proper cell pretreatment via anodic oxidation in an integrated reactive membrane filtration process. Our second stage of research (2016-2018) assessed the fouling characteristics of electrochemically reactive ceramic membranes (a Magneli phase suboxide of TiO2) when filtering algal suspension under different DC currents to achieve anodic or cathodic polarization as illustrated in the attached image. The critical flux results indicate that when applying positive or negative DC currents to the membrane both significantly mitigated membrane fouling and thus maintained higher critical fluxes compared to the critical flux without DC currents. Moreover, applying DC currents also enhanced membrane defouling processes and recovered high permeate flux better than hydraulic and chemical backwash methods. Moreover, fouling kinetics and the cake layer formation were analyzed with a resistance-in-series model that revealed many important but underexamined parameters (e.g., cake layer resistance, cake layer thickness, and cake concentration at membrane surface). The cake layer structures (thickness and compressibility) were microscopically examined and compared well with the model calculations, which provide new insight into the biofouling mechanisms.  The third stage of our research (2018-2019) evaluated the removal of multiple organic compounds (e.g., geosmin, dyes, 1,4-Dioxane) under different DC current densities on the reactive membrane. For instance, the potential released odor compounds from electrolyzed algal cells was shown to be effectively removed by this reactive membrane under positive DC currents. Overall, this study re-validated the mechanistic modeling framework on electrochemically reactive membrane filtration systems and furthers our understanding of fouling and antifouling processes. Such an accomplishment would be transformative and radically change the fields of Energy, Environmental and Chemical Engineering, and has broad impacts on broader industrial processes such as food production (e.g., wine or milk purification), drinking water treatment, bacterial separation, cellulose separation and oxidation, and biomolecule purification in pharmaceutical industries. 

Finally, our four stage of research (2017-2019) examined the market fits, value propositions and customer discovery/feedback on the demand of reactive membrane separation technologies in general. This research engaged undergraduate students of environmental and chemical engineering and high school interns to conduct literature survey and local interviews (partially supported by NSF I-Corp) to deliver new insights into future sustainable separation processes. Finally, this work significantly guides us in the process of desiginig and fabricating reactive membranes that meet customerized functions, utilize less hazadous chemicals or materials, and render low energy footprints. Besides, the integration of research into education was achieved through new teaching modules, laboratory manuals,and workshops targeted at a diverse student population. Interdisciplinary research training and educational activities were included in collaboration with industrial partners such as Passaic Valley water treatment plant in New Jersey. These partnerships and interactive workshops effectively disseminated our research outcomes to the public, potential customers, communities, municipalities, states, and drinking water managers.

Modified by: Wen Zhang

    Electrochemically reactive membrane filtration
